Subject Granular Differential Privacy in Federated Learning

Virendra J. Marathe virendra.marathe@oracle.com Oracle Labs ,Â  Pallika Kanani pallika.kanani@oracle.com Oracle Labs ,Â  Daniel Peterson daniel.peterson@oracle.com Oracle Labs Â andÂ  Guy Steele Jr guy.steele@oracle.com Oracle Labs
Abstract.

This paper considers subject level privacy in the FL setting, where a subject is an individual whose private information is embodied by several data items either confined within a single federation user or distributed across multiple federation users. We propose two new algorithms that enforce subject level DP at each federation user locally. Our first algorithm, called \localgroupdp, is a straightforward application of group differential privacy in the popular DP-SGD algorithm. Our second algorithm is based on a novel idea of hierarchical gradient averaging (\higradavg) for subjects participating in a training mini-batch. We also show that user level Local Differential Privacy (LDP) naturally guarantees subject level DP. We observe the problem of horizontal composition of subject level privacy loss in FL â€“ subject level privacy loss incurred at individual users composes across the federation. We formally prove the subject level DP guarantee for our algorithms, and also show their effect on model utility loss. Our empirical evaluation on FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets shows that \localgroupdpÂ delivers the best performance among our algorithms. However, its model utility lags behind that of models trained using a DP-SGD based algorithm that provides a weaker item level privacy guarantee. Privacy loss amplification due to subject sampling fractions and horizontal composition remain key challenges for model utility.

1. Introduction

Data privacy enforcement, using Differential Privacy (DP)Â (Dwork etÂ al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014), in the Federated Learning (FL) settingÂ (KonecnÃ½ etÂ al.,, 2015) has been explored at two granularities: (i) item level privacy, where use of each data item in model training is obfuscatedÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016); and (ii) user level privacy, where participation of each federation user is hiddenÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018).

Another dimension of DP in FL relates to the locale (physical location) of DP enforcement. The most common alternatives are (i) locally at federation usersÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016; Differential PrivacyÂ Team,, 2017; Truex etÂ al.,, 2020), and (ii) centrally at the federation serverÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018). The privacy enforcement locale is dictated by assumptions made about the trust model between federation users and the server. A trusted server enables central enforcement of DP at the server, whereas the users may prefer to locally enforce DP with an untrusted server.

In this paper, we assume that the federation users and the server behave as honest-but-curious participants in the federation: They do not interfere with or manipulate the distributed training protocol, but may be interested in analyzing received model updates. Federation users do not trust each other or the federation server, and must locally enforce privacy guarantees for their private data.

User level privacy is perhaps the right privacy granularity in the original cross-device FL setting consisting millions of hand held devicesÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al.,, 2019; KonecnÃ½ etÂ al.,, 2015). Furthermore, central enforcement of user level privacyÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018) appears to be the most viable approach in that setting. However, the cross-silo FL settingÂ (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2019), where federation users are organizations that are themselves gatekeepers of data items of numerous individuals (which we call â€œsubjectsâ€ henceforth), offer much richer mappings between subjects and their personal data.

In the simplest of use cases, a subject is embodied by a single data item across the entire federation. Thus item level privacy is sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy. However, many real world use cases exhibit more complex subject to data mappings. Consider a patient Pğ‘ƒP visiting different hospitals for treatment of different ailments. Each hospital contains multiple data records forming Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s health history. These hospitals may decide to participate in a federation that uses their respective patientsâ€™ health history records in their training datasets. Thus distinct health history records of the same data subject (e.g. Pğ‘ƒP) can appear in the datasets of multiple hospitals. In the end, it is the privacy of these subjects that we want to preserve in a FL federation.

Item level privacy, irrespective of its enforcement locale, does not suffice to protect privacy of Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s data. That is because item level privacy simply obfuscates participation of individual data items in the training processÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016; Dwork etÂ al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014). Since a subject may have multiple data items in the dataset, item level private training may still leak a subjectâ€™s data distributionÂ (Liu etÂ al.,, 2020; McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018). User level privacy enforced centrallyÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018) does not protect the privacy of Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s data either. User level privacy obfuscates each userâ€™s participation in trainingÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018). However, a subjectâ€™s data can be distributed among several users, and it can be leaked when aggregated through FL. In the worst case, multiple federation users may host only the data of a single subject. Thus Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s data distribution can be leaked even if individual usersâ€™ participation is obfuscated centrally.

In this paper, we consider a third granularity of privacy â€“ subject level privacyÂ (Wang etÂ al.,, 2021)111 Wang et al.Â (Wang etÂ al.,, 2021) identify what we call subjects in this paper as users in their paper., where a subject is an individual whose private data is spread across multiple data items, which can themselves be distributed across multiple federation users. The notion of subject level privacy is not new, and in fact appears in some of the original work on DPÂ (Dwork etÂ al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014). However, most existing work has either assumed a 111-to-111 mapping between subjects and data itemsÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016), or has treated subjects as individual silos of data (a.k.a.Â users) in a collaborative learning setting such as FLÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018). Recent work has addressed subject level privacy in a centralized settingÂ (Levy etÂ al.,, 2021), but no prior work has addressed the problem in a distributed collaborative learning setting such as FL. To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first study of subject level privacy in FL.

We formulate subject level privacy in terms of the classic definition of differential privacyÂ (Dwork etÂ al.,, 2006). We present two novel algorithms â€“ \localgroupdpÂ and \higradavgâ€“ that achieve subject level DP in the FL setting. We formally prove our algorithmsâ€™ subject level DP guarantee. We also show that user level Local Differential Privacy (LDP), called UserLDP, provides the subject level DP guarantee.

We observe that subject level privacy loss at individual federation users composes across users in the federation. We call this horizontal composition. We show that, in the worst case, horizontal composition is equivalent to composition of privacy loss in iterative computations such as ML model training over mini-batches. Consequently, the recent advances in adaptive composition resultsÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016; Dong etÂ al.,, 2019; Dwork etÂ al.,, 2010; Mironov,, 2017) apply to horizontal composition. This adds additional constraints on model training either in terms of additional noise injection or in terms of the amount of training permitted â€“ reduction in training rounds by a factor of 1s1ğ‘ \frac{1}{\sqrt{s}}, where sğ‘ s is the number of users sampled in a training round. These constraints adversely affect model utility.

We formally analyze utility loss of models trained with our algorithms in terms of excess population lossÂ (Bassily etÂ al.,, 2019, 2014), assuming Lğ¿L-Lipschitz convex loss functions. We show that, compared to the utility loss incurred by the item level DP enforcement algorithm by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016) (LocalItemDP), utility loss of models trained using \localgroupdp, UserLDP, and \higradavgÂ is affected significantly by different factors. In case of \localgroupdpÂ and UserLDP, the utility degradation is amplified by a quadractic factor of the group size per mini-batch (the group size for UserLDPÂ is the size of the mini-batch). For \higradavg, the utility degradation is amplified by a quadratic factor of the cardinality of the most frequently occuring subject in a federation userâ€™s dataset.

Our empirical evaluation results, using the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasetsÂ (Caldas etÂ al.,, 2018), reflect our formal analysis of utility loss: \localgroupdpÂ and UserLDPÂ incur significant model utility overheads (degradation over LocalItemDPÂ of 15%percent1515\% on FEMNIST and 18%percent1818\% on Shakespeare with \localgroupdp, and far worse with UserLDP). \higradavgÂ leads to model degradation over LocalItemDPÂ of 22%percent2222\% on FEMNIST, and much worse utility than even UserLDPÂ on Shakespeare. This leaves us with the open problem of building high utility algorithms that guarantee subject level DP in FL.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Relevant definitions appear inÂ Section 2. Our algorithms and horizontal composition are described inÂ Section 3; we also prove their subject level DP guarantee.Â Section 4 formally shows the utility loss incurred more generally by subject level DP enforcement, and specifically by our algorithms. Our empirical evaluation appears inÂ Section 5, followed by conclusion inÂ Section 6.

3. Enforcing Subject Level Differential Privacy

We assume a federation that contains a federation server that is responsible for (i) initialization and distribution of the model architecture to the federation users, (ii) coordination of training rounds, (iii) aggregation and application of model updates coming from different users in each training round, and (iv) redistribution of the updated model back to the users. Each federation user (i) receives updated models from the federation server, (ii) retrains the received models using its private training data, and (iii) returns updated model parameters to the federation server.

Our algorithms enforce subject level DP locally at each user. But to prove the privacy guarantee for any subject, across the entire federation, we must ensure that the local subject level DP guarantee composes correctly through the global aggregation, at the federation server, of parameter updates received from these users. To that end we break down the federated training round into two functions: (i) â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l}, the userâ€™s training algorithm that enforces subject level DP locally, and (ii) â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g}, the serverâ€™s operation that aggregates parameter updates received from all the users. We first present our algorithms for â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l} and show that they locally enforce subject level DP. Thereafter we show how an instance of â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} that simply averages parameter updates (at the federation server) composes the subject level DP guarantee across multiple users in the federation.

Our algorithms are based on a federated version of theÂ DP-SGDÂ algorithm by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016). DP-SGDÂ was originially not designed for FL, but can be easily extended to enforce item level DP in FL: The federation server samples a random set of users for each training round and sends them a request to perform local training. Each user trains the model locally using DP-SGD. Formally, the parameter update at step tğ‘¡t in DP-SGDÂ using a mini-batch of size bğ‘b can be summarized in the following equation:

The users ship back updated model parameters to the federation server, which averages the updates received from all the sampled users. The server redistributes the updated model and triggers another training round if needed. The original paperÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016) also proposed the moments accountant method for tighter composition of privacy loss bounds compared to prior work on strong compositionÂ (Dwork etÂ al.,, 2010). We call this described algorithm LocalItemDP.

3.1. Locally Enforced Group Level Differential Privacy

Intuitively, LocalItemDPÂ enforces item level DP by injecting noise proportional to any sampled data itemâ€™s influence in each mini-batch. In order to extend this approach to enforce subject level DP, we need to precisely calibrate noise proportional to a data subjectâ€™s influence on a mini-batchâ€™s gradients. A direct method to attain that is by obfuscating the effects of the group of data items belonging to the same subject. We can apply the formalism of group differential privacy to achieve this group level obfuscation. The following theorem is a restatement, in our notation, of Theorem 2.22.22.2 and the associated footnote 111 from Dwork and RothÂ (Dwork & Roth,, 2014), Â§2.3:

Theorem 3.2.

Any (Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private randomized algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’Ÿâ†’â„›:ğ’œâ†’ğ’Ÿâ„›\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is (kâ€‹Îµ,kâ€‹e(kâˆ’1)â€‹Îµâ€‹Î´ğ‘˜ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜1ğœ€ğ›¿k\varepsilon,ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private for groups of size kâ‰¥2ğ‘˜2k\geq 2. That is, for all D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğ’ŸD,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} such that Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} differ in at most kğ‘˜k data items, and for all SâŠ†â„›ğ‘†â„›S\subseteq\mathcal{R},

Definition 3.3.

We say that a randomized algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is (â„°,Î”â„°Î”\mathcal{E},\Delta)-group differentially private for a group size of gğ‘”g, if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-differentially private, where â„°=gâ€‹Ïµâ„°ğ‘”italic-Ïµ\mathcal{E}=g\epsilon, and Î”=gâ€‹e(gâˆ’1)â€‹ÏµÎ”ğ‘”superscriptğ‘’ğ‘”1italic-Ïµ\Delta=ge^{(g-1)\epsilon}.

In the FL setting, subject level DP immediately follows from group DP for every sampled mini-batch of data items at every federation user. Let â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} be a sampled mini-batch of data items at a user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, and â„›â„›\mathcal{R} be the domain space of the ML model being trained in the FL setting.

Theorem 3.4.

Composition of group DP guarantees over multiple mini-batches and training rounds also follows established DP composition resultsÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016; Dwork etÂ al.,, 2010; Mironov,, 2017). For instance, the moments accountant method by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016) shows that given an (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-DP gradient computation for a single mini-batch, the full training algorithm, which consists of Tğ‘‡T mini-batches and a mini-batch sampling fraction of qğ‘q, is (Oâ€‹(qâ€‹Îµâ€‹T),Î´)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğœ€ğ‘‡ğ›¿(O(q\varepsilon\sqrt{T}),\delta)-differentially private. We now present our new FL training algorithm, \localgroupdp, that guarantees group DP. We make a critical assumption in \localgroupdp: Each user can determine the subject for any of its data items. Absent this assumption, the user may need to make the worst case assumption that all data items used to train the model belong to the same subject. On the other hand, these algorithms are strictly local, and do not require that the identity of the subjects be resolved across users.

\localgroupdp

(Â Algorithm 1) enforces subject level privacy locally at each user. Like prior workÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016; McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018; Song etÂ al.,, 2013), we enforce DP in \localgroupdpÂ by adding carefully calibrated Gaussian noise in each mini-batchâ€™s gradients. Each user clips gradients for each data item in a mini-batch to a clipping threshold Cğ¶C prescribed by the federation server. The clipped gradients are subsequently averaged over the mini-batch. The clipping step bounds the sensitivity of each mini-batchâ€™s gradients to Cğ¶C.

To enforce group DP, \localgroupdpÂ also locally tracks the item count of the subject with the largest number of items in the sampled mini-batch (LrgGrpCnt(â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}) in Algorithm 1). This count determines the group size needed to enforce group DP for that mini-batch. This group size, Zğ‘Z inÂ Algorithm 1, helps determine the noise scale ÏƒZsubscriptğœğ‘\sigma_{Z}, given the target privacy parameters (â„°,Î”)â„°Î”(\mathcal{E},\Delta) over the entire training round. ÏƒZsubscriptğœğ‘\sigma_{Z} is computed using the moments accountant method. 3.2. Hierarchical Gradient Averaging

While \localgroupdpÂ may seem like a reasonable approach to enforce subject level DP, its utility penalty due to group DP can be significant. For instance, even a group of size 222 effectively halves the available privacy budget â„°â„°\mathcal{E} for training. The key challenge to enforce subject level DP is that the following constraint seems fundamental: To guarantee subject level DP, any training algorithm must obfuscate the entire contribution made by any subject in the modelâ€™s parameter updates. \localgroupdpÂ complies with this constraint by enforcing group DP.

Our new algorithm, called \higradavgÂ (Algorithm 2), takes a diametrically opposite view to comply with the same constraint: Instead of scaling the noise to a subjectâ€™s group size (as is done in \localgroupdp), \higradavgÂ scales down each subjectâ€™s mini-batch gradient contribution to the clipping threshold Cğ¶C. This is done in three steps: (i) collect data items belonging to a common subject in the sampled mini-batch, (ii) compute and clip gradients using the threshold Cğ¶C for each individual data item of the subject, and (iii) average those clipped gradients for the subject, denoted by gasubscriptğ‘”ğ‘g_{a}. Clipping and then averaging gradients ensures that the entire subjectâ€™s gradient norm is bounded by Cğ¶C.

Subsequently, \higradavgÂ sums all the per-subject averaged gradients along with the Gaussian noise, which are then averaged over the number of distinct subjects |sâ€‹uâ€‹bâ€‹jâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹tâ€‹sâ€‹(S)|ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘†|subjects(S)| sampled in the mini-batch Sğ‘†S. \higradavgÂ gets its name from this average-of-averages step. These two averaging steps have the result of mapping each subject ağ‘aâ€™s data itemsâ€™ gradients to a single representative averaged gradient for ağ‘a in the mini-batch Sğ‘†S.

The Gaussian noise scale Ïƒğœ\sigma is calculated independently at each user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} using standard parameters â€“ the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon, the failure probability Î´ğ›¿\delta and total number of mini-batches T.Rformulae-sequenceğ‘‡ğ‘…T.R over the entire multi-round training process. For the sampling fraction, we must consider sampling probability of individual subjects instead of data items. As a result, the subject sampling fraction becomes q=kâ€‹B|Di|ğ‘ğ‘˜ğµsubscriptğ·ğ‘–q=\frac{kB}{|D_{i}|}, where kğ‘˜k is the maximum number of data items belonging to any subject aâˆˆsâ€‹uâ€‹bâ€‹jâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹tâ€‹sâ€‹(â„¬)ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ â„¬a\in subjects(\mathcal{B}) in the dataset Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}. Composition of the privacy loss is done using the moments accountant methodÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016).

To formally prove that \higradavgÂ enforces subject level DP, we first provide a formal definition of subject sensitivity in a sampled mini-batch.

3.3. User Level Local Differential Privacy

While centrally enforced user level privacyÂ (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018) is not sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy, we observe that Local Differential Privacy (LDP)Â (Duchi etÂ al.,, 2013; Kasiviswanathan etÂ al.,, 2008; Warner,, 1965) is sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy. There are strong parallels between the traditional LDP setting, where a data analyst can get access to the data only after it has been perturbed, and privacy in the FL setting, where the federation server gets access to parameter updates from users after they have been locally perturbed by the users. In fact, LDP obfuscates the entire signal from a user to the extent that an adversary, even the federation server, cannot tell the difference between the signals coming from any two different users.

Definition 3.8.

We say that FL algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’Ÿğ’°â†’â„›:ğ’œâ†’subscriptğ’Ÿğ’°â„›\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D_{U}}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is user level (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-locally differentially private, where ğ’Ÿğ’°subscriptğ’Ÿğ’°\mathcal{D_{U}} is the dataset domain of users in set ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}, and â„›â„›\mathcal{R} is the model parameter domain, if for any two users u1,u2âˆˆğ’°subscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢2ğ’°u_{1},u_{2}\in\mathcal{U}, and SâŠ†â„›ğ‘†â„›S\subseteq\mathcal{R},

(5) Prâ€‹[ğ’œâ€‹(Du1)âˆˆS]â‰¤eÎµâ€‹Prâ€‹[ğ’œâ€‹(Du2)âˆˆS]+Î´Prdelimited-[]ğ’œsubscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘†superscriptğ‘’ğœ€Prdelimited-[]ğ’œsubscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢2ğ‘†ğ›¿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{u_{1}})\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{u_{2}})\in S]+\delta

where Du1subscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢1D_{u_{1}} and Du2subscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢2D_{u_{2}} are the datasets of users u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2} respectively.

We now present a new user level (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-LDP algorithm called UserLDP. The underlying intuition behind this algorithm is to let the user locally inject enough noise to make its entire signal indistinguishable from any other userâ€™s signal. In every training round, each federation user enforces user level LDP independently of the federation and any other users in the federation. The federation server simply averages parameter updates received from users and broadcasts the new averaged parameters back to the users.

UserLDPâ€™s pseudo code appears inÂ Algorithm 3. Note that UserLDPÂ appears very similar to DP-SGDÂ (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016). However, there are two significant differences between the two algorithms: First, while DP-SGDÂ scales the noise proportional to the gradient contribution of any single data item in a mini-batch, UserLDPÂ computes noise proportional to the gradient contribution of the entire mini-batch (line 999). To guarantee DP, we need to first cap the sensitivity of each user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}â€™s contribution to parameter updates. To that end, we focus on change affected by any mini-batch â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} trained at uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}. Line 777 inÂ Algorithm 3 ensures the following lemma.

3.4. Composition Over Multiple Training Rounds

Composition of privacy loss across multiple training rounds can be done by straightforward application of DP composition results, such as the moments accountant method that we use in our work. Thus the privacy loss Îµrsubscriptğœ€ğ‘Ÿ\varepsilon_{r} incurred in any single training round rğ‘Ÿr amplifies by a factor of Rğ‘…\sqrt{R} when federated training runs for Rğ‘…R rounds. We note that privacy losses are incurred by federation users independently of other federation users. Foreknowledge of the number of training rounds Rğ‘…R lets us calculate the Gaussian noise distributionâ€™s standard deviation Ïƒğœ\sigma for a privacy loss budget of (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta) for the aggregate training over Rğ‘…R rounds. Given an aggregate privacy loss budget of Îµğœ€\varepsilon, since all users train for an identical number of rounds Rğ‘…R, they incur a privacy loss of Îµr=ÎµRsubscriptğœ€ğ‘Ÿğœ€ğ‘…\varepsilon_{r}=\frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{R}} in each training round rğ‘Ÿr. Notably, this privacy loss per training round is the the same for all users even if their dataset cardinalities are dramatically different.

3.5. Composing Subject Level DP Across Federation Users

At the beginning of a training round rğ‘Ÿr, each sampled user receives a copy of the global model, with parameters Î˜râˆ’1subscriptÎ˜ğ‘Ÿ1\Theta_{r-1}, which it then retrains using its private data. Since all sampled users start retraining from the same model â„³Î˜râˆ’1subscriptâ„³subscriptÎ˜ğ‘Ÿ1\mathcal{M}_{\Theta_{r-1}}, and independently retrain the model using their respective private data, parallel composition of privacy loss across these sampled users may seem to apply naturallyÂ (McSherry,, 2009). In that case, the aggregate privacy loss incurred across multiple federation users, via an aggregation such as federated averaging, remains identical to the privacy loss Îµrsubscriptğœ€ğ‘Ÿ\varepsilon_{r} incurred individually at each user. However, parallel composition was proposed for item level privacy, where an item belongs to at most one participant. With subject level privacy, a subjectâ€™s data items can span across multiple users, which limits application of parallel privacy loss composition to only those federations where each subjectâ€™s data is restricted to at most one federation user. In the more general case, we show that subject level privacy loss composes adaptively via the federated averaging aggregation algorithm used in our FL training algorithms.

Formally, consider a FL training algorithm â„±=(â„±l,â„±g)â„±subscriptâ„±ğ‘™subscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), where â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l} is the user local component, and â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} the global aggregation component of â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. Given a federation user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, let â„±l:(â„³,Dui)â†’Î¸ui:subscriptâ„±ğ‘™â†’â„³subscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğœƒsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–\mathcal{F}_{l}:(\mathcal{M},D_{u_{i}})\rightarrow\theta_{u_{i}}, where â„³â„³\mathcal{M} is a model, Duisubscriptğ·subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–D_{u_{i}} is the private dataset of user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, and Î¸uisubscriptğœƒsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–\theta_{u_{i}} is the updated parameters produced by â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l}. Let â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} be 1nâ€‹âˆ‘iÎ¸ui1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğœƒsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\theta_{u_{i}}, a parameter update averaging algorithm over a set of nğ‘›n federation users uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}.

Theorem 3.12.

Given a FL training algorithm â„±=(â„±l,â„±g)â„±subscriptâ„±ğ‘™subscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), in the most general case where a subjectâ€™s data resides in the private datasets of multiple federation users uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, the aggregation algorithm â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} adaptively composes subject level privacy losses incurred by â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l} at each federation user.

We term this composition of privacy loss across federation users as horizontal composition. Horizontal composition has a significant effect on the number of federated training rounds permitted under a given privacy loss budget.

Theorem 3.13.

Consider a FL training algorithm â„±=(â„±l,â„±g)â„±subscriptâ„±ğ‘™subscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}) that samples sğ‘ s users per training round, and trains the model â„³â„³\mathcal{M} for Rğ‘…R rounds. Let â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l} at each participating user, over the aggregate of Rğ‘…R training rounds, locally enforce subject level (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-DP. Then â„±â„±\mathcal{F} globally enforces the same subject level (Îµğœ€\varepsilon,Î´ğ›¿\delta)-DP guarantee by training for Rsğ‘…ğ‘ \frac{R}{\sqrt{s}} rounds.

The main intuition behindÂ TheoremÂ 3.13 is that the sğ‘ s-way horizontal composition via â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} results in an increase in training mini-batches by a factor of sğ‘ s. As a result, the privacy loss calculated by the moments accountant method amplifies by a factor of sğ‘ \sqrt{s}, thereby forcing a reduction in number of training rounds by a factor of sğ‘ \sqrt{s} to counteract the privacy loss amplification. This reduction in training rounds can have a significant impact on the resulting modelâ€™s performance, as we demonstrate inÂ sectionÂ 5. Proofs forÂ Theorem 3.12 andÂ Theorem 3.13 appear in the appendix.

An alternate approach to account for horizontal composition of privacy loss is to simply scale the number of training minibatches (called lots by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016)) by the number of federation users sampled in each training round. The scaled minibatch (lot) count can be used by each user to privately calculate the noise scale Ïƒğœ\sigma at the beginning of the entire federated training process. An increase in the number of total minibatches does lead to a significant increase in the noise introduced in each minibatchâ€™s gradients, resulting in model performance degradation.

4. Utility Loss

Our utility loss formalism leverages a long line of former work on differentially private empirical risk minimization (ERM)Â (Bassily etÂ al.,, 2019, 2014; Chaudhuri etÂ al.,, 2011; Duchi etÂ al.,, 2013; Iyengar etÂ al.,, 2019; Kifer etÂ al.,, 2012; Song etÂ al.,, 2013; Talwar etÂ al.,, 2015; Thakurta & Smith,, 2013; Wang etÂ al.,, 2018). In particular, we extend the notation of, and heavily base our formal analysis on work by Bassily et al.Â (Bassily etÂ al.,, 2019), applying it to subject level DP in general, with specializations for our individual algorithms.

4.3. Utility Loss for \higradavg

It instead scales down the gradients of all data items of the subject to a single data itemâ€™s gradient bounds (established by the clipping threshold). As a result, the noise amplification we showed for \localgroupdpÂ does not exist for \higradavg. However, scaling down the gradient signal of a subject does indeed affect \higradavgâ€™s utility. 5. Empirical Evaluation

We implemented all our algorithms UserLDP, \localgroupdp, and \higradavg, and a version of the DP-SGD algorithm by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al.,, 2016) that enforces item level DP in the FL setting (LocalItemDP). We also compare these algorithms with a FL training algorithm, FedAvgÂ (KonecnÃ½ etÂ al.,, 2015), that does not enforce any privacy guarantees. All our algorithms are implemented in our distributed FL framework built on distributed PyTorch.

We focus our evaluation on Cross-Silo FLÂ (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2019), which we believe is the most appropriate setting for the subject level privacy problem. We use the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasetsÂ (Caldas etÂ al.,, 2018) for our evaluation. In FEMNIST, the hand-written numbers and letters can be divided based on authors, which ordinarily serve as federation users in FL experiments by most researchers. In Shakespeare, each character in the Shakespeare plays serves as a federation user. In our experiments however, the FEMNIST authors and Shakespeare play characters are treated as data subjects. To emulate the cross-silo FL setting, we report evaluation on a 16-user federation.

We use the CNN model on FEMNIST appearing in the LEAF benchmark suiteÂ (Caldas etÂ al.,, 2018) as our target model to train. More specifically, the model consists of two convolution layers interleaved with ReLU activations and maxpooling, followed by two fully connected layers before a final log softmax layer. For the Shakespeare dataset we use a stacked LSTM model with two linear layers at the end.

We use 80%percent8080\% of the training data for training, and 20%percent2020\% for validation. Test data comes separately in FEMNIST and Shakespeare. Training and testing was done on a local GPU cluster comprising 222 nodes, each containing 888 Nvidia Tesla V100 GPUs.

We extensively tuned the hyperparameters of mini-batch size BğµB, number of training rounds Tğ‘‡T, gradient clipping threshold Cğ¶C, and learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta. The final hyperparameters for FEMNIST were: B=512ğµ512B=512, T=100ğ‘‡100T=100, C=0.001ğ¶0.001C=0.001, and learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta of 0.0010.0010.001 and 0.010.010.01 for the non-private and private FL algorithms respectively. Shakespeare hyperparameters were: B=100ğµ100B=100, T=200ğ‘‡200T=200, C=0.00001ğ¶0.00001C=0.00001, and learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta of 0.00020.00020.0002 and 0.010.010.01 for the non-private and private FL algorithms.

In our implementations of all our algorithms UserLDP, \localgroupdp, and \higradavg, we used the privacy loss horizontal composition accounting technique that reduces the number of training rounds by sğ‘ \sqrt{s}, where sğ‘ s is the number of sampled users per training round. We experimented with the alternative approach that scales up the number of minibatches by sğ‘ s to calculate a larger noise scale Ïƒğœ\sigma, but this approach consistently yielded worse model utility than our first approach. Hence here we report only the performance of our first approach.

5.1. FEMNIST and Shakespeare Performance

We first conduct an experiment that reports average test accuracy and loss at the end of each training round, over a total of 100100100 and 200200200 training rounds for FEMNIST and Shakespeare respectively. The FEMNIST dataset contains 350035003500 subjects, and the Shakespeare dataset contains 660660660 subjects. In FEMNIST, the average number of data items per subject is 145145145, whereas in case of Shakespeare it is 4,48444844,484. As we shall see later in this section, these subject cardinalities significantly contribute to performance of our algorithmsâ€™ models. Each subjectâ€™s data items are uniformly distributed among the 161616 federation users.

FigureÂ 1 shows performance of the models trained using our algorithms. FedAvgÂ performs the best since it does not incur any DP enforcement penalties. Item level privacy enforcement in LocalItemDPÂ results in performance degradation of 8%percent88\% for FEMNIST and 22%percent2222\% for Shakespeare. The utility cost of user level LDP in UserLDPÂ is quite clear from the figure. This cost is also reflected in the relatively high observed loss for the respective model. \localgroupdpÂ performs significantly better than UserLDP, but worse than LocalItemDP, by 15%percent1515\% on FEMNIST, and 18%percent1818\% on Shakespeare. The reason for \localgroupdpâ€™s worse performance is clear fromÂ FigureÂ 2(a) and (c): the group size for a mini-batch tends to be dominated by 333 on both FEMNIST and Shakespeare, which cuts the privacy budget for these mini-batches by a factor of 333, leading to greater Gaussian noise, which in turn leads to model performance degradation.

\higradavg

performs worse than \localgroupdpÂ because we need to use the sampling fraction of largest cardinality subjects at federation users when calculating mini-batch noise scale (TheoremÂ 3.7). This amounts to noise scale amplification by approximately an order of magnitude. This amplification is much higher for Shakespeare (with an average of 4,48444844,484 data items per subject) by another order of magnitude, because of which \higradavgâ€™s modelâ€™s utility is the worst. Moreover, privacy loss amplification due to horizontal composition limits the amount of training thereby further limiting model utility (in all our algorithms).

5.2. Effect of Subject Data Distribution

While evaluation of our algorithms using a uniform distribution of subject data among federation users is a good starting point, often times the data distribution is non-uniform in real world settings. To emulate varying subject data distributions, we conduct experiments on the FEMNIST dataset where subject data is distributed among federation users according to the power distribution

Pâ€‹(x;Î±)=Î±â€‹xÎ±âˆ’1,0â‰¤xâ‰¤1,Î±>0formulae-sequenceformulae-sequenceğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¼superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼10ğ‘¥1ğ›¼0\displaystyle P(x;\alpha)=\alpha x^{\alpha-1},0\leq x\leq 1,\alpha>0

FigureÂ 3 shows performance of the models trained using our algorithms over varying subject data distributions of FEMNIST. As expected, different data distributions clearly do not significantly affect FedAvg, LocalItemDP, and User-Local-SGD. However, performance of the model trained using \localgroupdpÂ degrades noticeably as the unevenness of data distribution increases, resulting in test accuracy under 50%percent5050\% for Î±=16ğ›¼16\alpha=16. This degradation is singularly attributable to growth in subject group size per mini-batch â€“ the average group size per mini-batch ranges from 333 when Î±=2ğ›¼2\alpha=2 to 666 when Î±=16ğ›¼16\alpha=16. This increase in group size significantly reduces the privacy budget leading to increase in Gaussian noise that restricts test accuracy. On the other hand, though \higradavgâ€™s model utility is much lower than that of \localgroupdpâ€™s, it appears to be much more resilient to non-uniform subject data distributions among federation users up to Î±=8ğ›¼8\alpha=8, and therafter drops noticeably at Î±=16ğ›¼16\alpha=16.

6. Conclusion

While various prior works on privacy in FL have explored DP guarantees at the user and item levelsÂ (Liu etÂ al.,, 2020; McMahan etÂ al.,, 2018), to the best of our knowledge, no prior work has studied subject level granularity for privacy in the FL setting. In this paper, we presented a formal definition of subject level DP. We also presented three novel FL training algorithms that guarantee subject level DP by either enforcing user level LDP (UserLDP), local group DP (\localgroupdp), or by applying hierarchical gradient averaging to obfuscate a subjectâ€™s contribution to mini-batch gradients (\higradavg). Our formal analysis over convex loss functions shows that all our algorithms affect utility loss in interesting ways, with \localgroupdpÂ incurring lower utility loss than UserLDPÂ and \higradavg. Our empirical evaluation on the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets aligns with our formal analysis showing that while both UserLDPÂ and \higradavgÂ can significantly degrade model performance, \localgroupdpÂ tends to incur much less loss in model performance compared to LocalItemDP, an algorithm that provides a weaker item level privacy guarantee. We also observe an interesting new aspect of horizontal composition of privacy loss for subject level privacy in FL that results in model performance degradation. Both our formal and empirical analysis demonstrate that there remains significant room for model utility improvements in algorithms that guarantee subject level DP in FL.

Given a FL training algorithm â„±=(â„±l,â„±g)â„±subscriptâ„±ğ‘™subscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), in the most general case where a subjectâ€™s data resides in the private datasets of multiple federation users uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, the aggregation algorithm â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} adaptively composes subject level privacy losses incurred by â„±lsubscriptâ„±ğ‘™\mathcal{F}_{l} at each federation user.

Proof.

Assume two distinct users u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2} in a federation that host private data items of subject sğ‘ s. Let Îµ1subscriptğœ€1\varepsilon_{1} and Îµ2subscriptğœ€2\varepsilon_{2} be the respective subject privacy losses incurred by the two users during a training round.

Thus parameter averaging done by â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g} simply results in summation and scaling of these disjoint parameter updates. As a result, the privacy losses, Îµ1subscriptğœ€1\varepsilon_{1} and Îµ2subscriptğœ€2\varepsilon_{2} incurred by u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2} respectively are retained to their entirety by â„±gsubscriptâ„±ğ‘”\mathcal{F}_{g}.
